title: Viktoria (trophy)
text:
The Viktoria, formerly spelled "Victoria", is a German <a href="association%20football">association football</a> trophy which was awarded to the <a href="List%20of%20German%20football%20champions">German champions</a> from <a href="1903%20German%20football%20championship">1903</a> to <a href="1944%20German%20football%20championship">1944</a>. It is modelled on <a href="Victoria%20%28mythology%29">Victoria</a>, the Roman goddess of victory, winged and flinging a wreath. Thus it is the smaller reproduction of a life size sculpture to be found in <a href="Berlin">Berlin's</a> <a href="Alte%20Nationalgalerie">Old National Gallery</a>.
History.
The "Victoria" was awarded to the <a href="German%20Football%20Association">German Football Association</a>, the "DFB", in 1900 to commemorate Germany's participation in the <a href="1900%20Summer%20Olympics">1900 Summer Olympics</a> which were held alongside the <a href="Exposition%20Universelle%20%281900%29">1900 World Fair</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>.
Originally it was meant as a trophy for both the German association football and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> <a href="German%20rugby%20union%20championship">champions</a> but it was first awarded to the inaugural German football champions <a href="VfB%20Leipzig">VfB Leipzig</a> on 31 May 1903. After 1903 it was annually given to the German champions except during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> when the competition was halted. The last club to receive the trophy was <a href="Dresdner%20SC">Dresdner SC</a> in 1944 after which it went missing in the final stages of the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>.
In post-Second World War Germany a new trophy had to be commissioned to replace the missing "Victoria", the "<a href="Meisterschale">Meisterschale</a>", when the German championship resumed in <a href="1948%20German%20football%20championship">1948</a>, which was available from <a href="1949%20German%20football%20championship">1949</a> onwards. The trophy resurfaced after the <a href="German%20reunification">German reunification</a>, with its whereabouts in the time between remaining obscured, with theories ranging from the trophy being kept by the <a href="East%20German">East German</a> government to it being hidden in a cellar in <a href="East%20Berlin">East Berlin</a>, and was kept at the "DFB" headquarters in <a href="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a> until it was relocated to the new <a href="German%20football%20museum">German football museum</a> in <a href="Dortmund">Dortmund</a> in 2015.
